body: @legendtkl can you also update in the "master" docs for next versions? https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/master/site2/docs/client-libraries-go.md

@nanguawu 

I think current hdfs connector is tied to 3.x first. we need to do some adjustment to support hdfs 2.x. will take a look at how to get to it.

@sijie I am not sure why the test fails during testing. I am able to run the test successfully locally using TestNG 6.13.1.  Do we use a different version of TestNG on Jenkins?  

The error is related to the TestNG regex not matching the expected string, but as you can see from visual inspection that the String should match.

"@Test(expectedExceptions = com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.exc.InvalidFormatException.class,
            expectedExceptionsMessageRegExp = "Can not deserialize value of type java.lang.Boolean from String .*")

@sijie Seems this is not able to produce. And the code that used in NamespacesImpl.java has already identified v1/v2 ns.
```
    private WebTarget namespacePath(NamespaceName namespace, String... parts) {
        final WebTarget base = namespace.isV2() ? adminV2Namespaces : adminNamespaces;
        WebTarget namespacePath = base.path(namespace.toString());
        namespacePath = WebTargets.addParts(namespacePath, parts);
        return namespacePath;
    }
```

I am using a standalone cluster, and set --limit 1k, and test could not produce more data when limit reached.

Now verified same issue on a full Pulsar setup.
@jiazhai great! let's close it as "not valid anymore"

run java8 tests
run integration tests

> Can you also clarify on the ConsumerBuilder javadoc how the priority is being used?

yes, added.
I think the problem might be related to concurrent updates on namespace policy. we can probably handle the bad version and retry, or put all the updates on same namespace in ordered executor.

Yes, the zookeeper bad version implies that pulsar have concurrent updates.
At least a retry is needed. Don't know if a queue would help, do you only
have one entry point? Otherwise, you would still have potential concurrent
updates.
Harald
@merlimat Thanks, will check and do the fix
@rdhabalia One more question: how would this impact the assignment across multiple partitions?

+1. Supporting gRPC would give access to a lot more clients, integration with reactive frameworks (like RxJava or Reactor), provide application-level flow control, etc...
Another stream protocol to watch IMO is [RSocket.io](http://rsocket.io/) which has built-in integration of reactive-streams spec (non blocking streams with back-pressure). Since it was just released, it lacks client SDKs but that should evolve over time.

run java8 tests
run integration tests

@risson Yes, a consumer instance is able to acknowledge a message that was dispatched to a different consumer. The only thing you need to have is the `MessageId`, which can also be serialized into a `byte[]` and stored somewhere.

There is the plan to implement the concept of "replicated subscriptions" in open-source Apache Pulsar, to have precise failover to a different cluster. We didn't get to actually implement it yet, but it's planned for near future. 

Workarounds for that are: 
 * Use active-active consumers (consume and process in both clusters)
 * Do manual failover and reset subscription to a timestamp. eg: Cluster A failed, move consumers to cluster B and rollback to 10 minutes earlier. Some amount of duplicates will occur in this case.

> Use active-active consumers (consume and process in both clusters)

In that case a message produced in one cluster will be consumed twice, once per cluster right ? It's not really what I want (eg. if the consumer sends mails, 2 mails are sent...)

> Do manual failover and reset subscription to a timestamp. eg: Cluster A failed, move consumers to cluster B and rollback to 10 minutes earlier. Some amount of duplicates will occur in this case.

Yes resetting the subscription is what is done with Confluent with strategies to minimize duplicates (like storing consumption timestamps). I was wondering if something built-in existed in Pulsar but it seems not yet.

> how would this impact the assignment across multiple partitions?

priority-level gets configured at consumer level so, each partitioned-consumer will present its priority-level to broker and broker chooses active consumer for each partition. Each partitioned will be a separate topic so, there will not be any behavior difference in case of multiple partitions.

The question is that broker is using ordinal position for consumers to ensure even distribution. 

Simple example: 4 partitions, 2 consumers. With equal priorities, they 

partition | consumer
-------| ----
 t-partition-0 | c-1 
 t-partition-1 | c-2 
 t-partition-2 | c-1 
 t-partition-3 | c-2 

If I set c-1 with higher priority, I would expect to have c1 on all the partitions. however the priority will only affect the sorting, so each partition will see the same list of consumers `[c1, c2]`, ordered by priority, but will keep doing the same assigment as above, given that on partition-3 with chose the consumer index with `N % len(consumers)`

> The question is that broker is using ordinal position for consumers to ensure even distribution.
If I set c-1 with higher priority, I would expect to have c1 on all the partitions. 

that's true, I missed it. if we have C1 (priority=1), C2  (priority=0), C3  (priority=0) then C2,C3 consumers with highest priority should serve partitions evenly. let me fix it.
